title: N2 and H2 - metal added to reaction system

content.description:
Samples of <math alttext="N 2 gas" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2 gas" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are placed in a rigid container at a constant temperature of <math alttext="315 kelvin" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>315</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and allowed to react according to the following equation.

<math alttext="N 2 gas plus 3 H 2 gas reacts to produce 2 N H 3 gas" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question:
The synthesis of ammonia is carried out in three glass vessels of equal volume. In each vessel, <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> both have an initial partial pressure of <math alttext="3.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. A small piece of iron is added to one vessel, and a small piece of nickel is added to another vessel. The temperature is kept constant, and the pressure is measured at regular intervals, as shown in the table.

Total Pressure in Reaction Vessel

Time
 Glass
 Glass with Iron Added
 Glass with Nickel Added

<math alttext="0 minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="30 minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mtext> min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.8 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.8</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.8 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.8</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="60 minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn><mtext> min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.6 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.6</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.6 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.6</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="90 minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn><mtext> min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.5 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.5</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.5 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.5</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Which of the following explains the results shown in the table?

choices.label: Both iron and nickel are inhibitors; they prevent the system from reaching equilibrium.

Both iron and nickel are catalysts; more <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are consumed in the iron and nickel vessels than in the glass vessel, reducing the overall pressure.

Both iron and nickel react strongly with <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, causing it to decompose into <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, reducing the overall pressure.
Solids do not appear in the equilibrium expression, so the partial pressures of the gases are not affected by the metal.

content.answer: Both iron and nickel are catalysts; more <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are consumed in the iron and nickel vessels than in the glass vessel, reducing the overall pressure.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
